Pre-Game Insights: Fans from all over the world are flocking to Melbourne for the sold-out T20 World Cup cricket clash between India and Pakistan.
The Australian Bureau of Meteorology has predicted a 90 percent chance of rain on Sunday 23 October 2022, the day the two archrivals go head-to-head at the 2022 T20 World Cup.
Some 15 to 30 mm of rainfall is predicted on the day.
Ajaz Beg and his two friends, Nadeem and Amjad Hussain, are travelling to Australia from the UK to support Pakistan.
Ajaz questioned the International Cricket Council’s (ICC) decision to host the tournament during Melbourne’s wettest month.
Ajaz and his friends anticipate a close match if it does go ahead.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The two countries haven't played a bilateral cricket series since 2013 due to political tensions.

On its website, the ICC confirms that reserve days have been scheduled for both semi-finals and the final. However, no other matches will have a reserve day. In case of no play, both teams will be given one point each.
Others: Fan anger as scalped tickets for India-Pakistan T20 World Cup cricket clash sell for up to $500.

Pakistan fan Syed Raheel Mustafa was planning to travel by road from Sydney to Melbourne, with an overnight stop in Albury, as part of a convoy of three families in five vehicles. But now they are rethinking the whole trip due to the rain prediction.
Hasnain Ali Badri, a Perth-based India fan, has cancelled his plan to go to Melbourne for a week due to the unpredictable weather.
Bushra Kalam from Cairns had been excited to go to Melbourne, but her plans are now uncertain due to the weather forecast.
Zeeshan Iqbal, another cricket fan from Sydney, is already in Melbourne ahead of the match and remains hopeful that the match will go ahead.
